title: 107_s691
content: The Washoe Tribe Land Conveyance is addressed in Section 1. Congress finds that the Washoe Tribe's ancestral homeland in the Lake Tahoe region was recognized as indigenous territory in 1997, with objectives to support their traditional land use and cultural practices. The Act aims to support the Washoe Tribe's traditional and customary uses of National Forest System land, including access to Lake Tahoe for cultural practices. It also seeks to return the Tribe to Lake Tahoe and ensure opportunities for traditional activities like spiritual renewal and land stewardship. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey land to the Secretary of the Interior in trust for the Tribe. The Act supports the Washoe Tribe's traditional uses of National Forest System land, including access to Lake Tahoe for cultural practices. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey approximately 24.3 acres of land to the Secretary of the Interior in trust for the Tribe, with a reservation of a nonexclusive easement for public access over Forest Development Road #15N67. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a nonexclusive easement for public and administrative access over Forest Development Road #15N67 to National Forest System land for the Washoe Tribe. The Tribe will have vehicular access for administrative and safety purposes, including for members with disabilities. The use of the conveyed parcel is limited to traditional and customary uses, with no permanent residential, recreational, or commercial development allowed. The Tribe must limit the use of the parcel to traditional and customary uses, prohibit permanent residential or commercial development, and comply with environmental requirements. If the Secretary of the Interior finds that the Tribe has violated these terms, corrective action must be taken. If the Secretary of the Interior finds that the Tribe has used the parcel in violation of terms and fails to take corrective action, title to the parcel will revert to the Secretary of Agriculture. The bill was passed by the Senate on August 1, 2002, with Jeri Thomson as the Secretary.
